reviewText:
Dr. Langeskov, The TIger, and The Terribly Cursed Emerald is a phenominal game by the same people who directed The Stanley Parable. So if you liked Stanley, there's a good bet you'll love Dr. Langeskov. While the style of the game is very different, in that it's a stealthy heist game as opposed to a walking simulator with buttons, the narration and general voice acting of the characters really bring out the best in it.

Pros:Very tight controls
The stealth mechanics are very intuitive, and the guard's AI aren't braindead like most stealth games
As said above, incredible voice acting for all the characters. Dr. Langeskov himself being voiced by Gary Oldman was a hilarious choice.
The tiger. I can't say anymore without spoiling a lot of the game.
Cons:The grappling controls can be a bit finicky, especially on corners.
Excessive exploration shows just how quickly this game was made, with invisible walls bounding you into areas. Not that bad if you stay on track though.
The buttons on the elevator midway through seem to be bugged, it took a lot of clicking around to actually start it.
All in all, this is a free game with fantastic humor, grappling hooks, a giant emerald that you get to steal, and one of the tensest chase scenes with a tiger that you'll ever play.

tl;dr: Buy this game

Edit: Don't buy it, it's free. Just download it instead.

Ok, this game is pretty good, especially considering it's free. A fun little stealth game with a cool environment and some great moments (that tiger, man).

That being said, it could use a lot of improvements. The game in general seems pretty buggy, and I encountered some very strange things;

4. The sound. THIS is the big one. I constantly heard footsteps and the sounds of things crashing from outside the map, places I couldn't even get to. There was also a time when an alarm randomly triggered, despite the fact that I KNOW I didn't break stealth. It was weird.
5. And to top it all off? My game reset, right in the middle of everything. I was SO CLOSE to the Emerald, too.

That being said, there were some great parts of this game. The tranquilizer gun was satisfying to use, the grappling hook controlled better than I thought it would (even if it wasn't perfect) and the laser puzzle was really, really cool (even if it was buggy).

All in all, I'd recommend it for a free game. I'm hoping to see more of this stuff in the future, this game has potential.

reviewText:
Dr. Langeskov, The Tiger and The Terribly Cursed Emerald: A Whirlwind Heist is an exploration game developed by Crows Crows Crows. The game was released in December 2015 for free on Steam.

Gameplay in Dr. Langeskov is simple. You are in a first person perspective, and you have limited interaction with the game world. There are a number of items in the game that you can pick up for extra bits of narrative on which are worth a read if you are so inclined. Normally I am very negative about these types of games such as Gone Home, but this game felt different. The narration is done perfectly, by none other than Simon Amstel with clever wit and charm shining through.

The graphics in the game are very clean and well presented, with some very nicely done animations on the few objects that do move too. The plot is quite strange too, without spoiling it; this is a game that is set inside another game, an aspect this is portrayed very well.  There is no difficulty at all, as long as you follow the narrators instructions you won’t get lost or stuck.  On top of the story, there are a few little Easter eggs that you can find which relate to the game’s achievements, so it’s well worth spending a bit of time to explore your surroundings in game.

The title is only about twenty minutes long, and I was happy with the length. It’s a short story which has quite a bit of comical value, and some of the best narration I’ve heard in a game for a long while. If you do all of the achievements in one run through, there are no reason to play more than once, since the ending is the same regardless of your actions.

I didn’t have any technical problems, the game runs in the Unity engine so is very well optimized, with the options to play in tons of different resolutions and controller support too. There are limited graphical options, but the game should run fairly well on any machine given how well it is optimized.

To sum up, Dr. Langeskov, The Tiger and The Terribly Cursed Emerald: A Whirlwind Heist is well worth twenty minutes of your time to play through, it’s free so you may as well try it out. I am looking forward to seeing what Crows Crows Crows come up with next!

reviewText:
As a developer, when one of your fold was also a part of making a game like the incredibly well received (and entirely deserving) The Stanley Parable, for better or worse anything they touch is going to have a lot of baggage with it as high expectations will surely follow. But as it happens, this game more than lives up to it, and even manages to make its greatness seem effortless in the process.

I didn't know anything about the game before going into it - it just showed up on Steam one day, I saw it was free and short, and so I just instantly dived right in. I'm so glad I did, too, as I really think that's the best way for everyone to approach it as well. What I think I can safely say, though, is it's a first-person game very much in the style of The Stanley Parable, except where that was a game largely about the player (arguably. Unless I got it very, very wrong), this is more about the makers and the perceptions around them (arguably. Unless I got it very, very wrong). I feel like if I say any more about it then I'd risk spoiling it, so I'm just gonna shut my gob about the story now.

Speaking of being gobby, easily the best attraction at the fair here is the voice-over work provided by British comedian, Simon Amstell, who accompanies you throughout the entire course of your journey. He does such an amazing job that I really can't imagine anyone else playing the role, bringing with him an affable warmth that seems to come naturally and makes for a very welcome companion where most other games would more than likely have unwittingly made such a character an annoyance. By itself, this would have gotten the game pretty far, but what helps it really go the distance is the writing which hits its target beautifully every time. I've touched upon it before in previous reviews, but it never ceases to amaze me how much indie developers hit the nail on the head so perfectly when it comes to writing and acting, while big budget, triple-A studios churn out so many painfully cringey examples that sound like they could be straight from a Saturday morning kid's TV show. In fact, I think this may even set the new gold standard for me, perhaps just about trumping out Wheatley in Portal 2... though I may back down on that if I play them both again.

Given that the whole thing clocks in at roughly 20 minutes and has little reply value beyond a few minor variations in dialogue (although I was more than happy to play it through multiple times), there's not much else to say about it, and honestly, you really are better off just playing it and finding out for yourself what it's like. If you're reading this and somehow haven't played the game yet, I'd urge you to, then go tell everyone else you know to do the same since there's nothing to lose by giving it a shot and so much good stuff to take away from it. And while you're at it I also think it's worth keeping an eye on Crows Crows Crows to see what other delightful treats the studio might have for us in future.

I'll be honest. I only downloaded this game for the achievements. It's just free, you know? But I did not expect what I got.

The voice acting is, should I say, outstanding. I take it most of the NPCs are just there for comical effect, but I really do feel for them and their struggle. I really do.

All in all, not bad. It might even win some BAFTA awards.

reviewText:
An interesting little game that definitely made me laugh out loud a few times.

I love The Stanley Parable, so of course I would like this game. It's not really a long game at all, but that's fine. It is still fun, and for its style, it probably would've gotten annoying if it was too long and exactly the same way (i.e., linear, whereas The Stanley Parable had different paths).

I went into the game blind. Granted, it is a new game, but it doesn't seem that difficult to find out what it's about. So what I mean is that I literally didn't read forum posts, or reviews, or even the store's description (so I completely missed the sarcasm and how it works with the actual game). reviewText:
This truly came out of nowhere. I didn't know how much I liked heists until after I finished the game, but Dr. Langeskov, The Tiger, and the Terribly Crused Emerald is a modern day classic. Everything may not work in a seameless fashion, but the game's atmosphere more than makes up for it.

That breathtaking view of the mansion from the distance is worth the time it takes to trek through the forest. When the lights slowly flicker to life, it sets a fire in your eyes to explore. I can't seem to explain why the lights come on at different times in subsequent playthroughs, but that is okay.

Once inside, the game mechanics start to come to life. You can steal practically everything like coins, brooms and post-it notes (I suppose you're a low stakes kind of criminal). You work from room to room and can evade guards at your own leisure. The AI isn't too great, but it does feel like playing against some other player.

You get to evade a tiger that conspicuously goes missing once you leave the room. It's almost like you're being tailed by a clean-up crew, which might explain why the guards go missing. Either way, it's a thrilling escape that leads you outside the mansion and into the eye of the storm.

This is where some of the technical limitations of LTT come up. The rain starts off super heavy, then lightens up a bit. Lightning strikes at random and totally out of sync with the storm. Sometimes it stays dormat for awhile without even occuring. I think the programming is just messed up.

Still, you quickly get back into the mansion and learn the emerald is on the bottom floor. You take to the elevator, which also seems reliant on some unknown force in the code. Sometimes the elevator zips down fast and others, I was left waiting for what seemed like eons. I have no idea why.

The game kind of peters out after that. You get the emerald and the level design points to some fire happening, but nothing comes up. You just get to leave and that is the end. The rain gets a bit intense, but nothing else.

Either way, the game is truly remarkable. The short length of it makes repeat playthroughs a joy and the random nature of it's elements adds a whole new layer of believability. I can't say I've played many games like this.

9/10

reviewText:
Spoiler Warning! Try the game before reading this review, it's free!
First of all, this is an excellent game overall. The heist is great, and the bonus thefts are pretty great too. The whole game uses adventurous new concepts, like being able to choose your own path with rippling effects throughout the story. One such circumstance is stealing all of the oranges in the orangery, which curses the gem with the soul of your great, great uncle, who will tell you all about his childhood while chastising you for all of the modern mannerisms you have. (Such as using a phone instead of a map)

Without many spoilers, my favorite part of the game overall was the part where you had to fight the tiger while on a catwalk above the beluga whale tank with only a broken wrench and a toothpick. It's situations like these that made me really fall in love with this game. Another notable section when you have to grappling hook over to the platform with all the pencils on it and steal the oddly shaped paperclip which ended up being the key to vault 214.

Overall, this is an excellent game, especially for the price (which is free).So I would highly recommended to anyone who does not suffer from arachnophobia, as this condition could cause you develop extreme aversion to this game. So if you do not have narcolepsy, try Dr. Langeskov, The Tiger, and The Terribly Cursed Emerald: A Whirlwind Heist. (because it's free)

reviewText:
As a fan of stealth games, this game has earned a spot on the list of favorites.  Top of the list?  Heavens, no!  Keep in mind, however, that this is a free game!  The controls are pretty tight and the guard AI is better than in most games, but you can tell the studio maybe could have ironed out some other issues a bit more.  For instance, sometimes the lighting is a bit wonky.  Sometimes seemingly for no reason loading screens will take forever, and other times be nothing at all!  The button to get the elevator to work seemed a little off; I'm not sure if there is a sweet spot for it or what, I've played the game a few times now and sometimes it takes a few clicks to get the damn thing to take you up!  Speaking of elevators, the game sometimes has visual artifacts: I swear I could see an unused character just standing around behind the elevator.  Again, free game, a few bugs here and there are nothing compared to the great time you'll have.  The grappling hook feels right, and you can use it to get some pretty cool views when it comes to planning your paths.  Oh, speaking of planning: the Tiger is pretty damn smart.  Well done, Mr. Coder!  It seemed like everytime I thought I had shaken it off my tale it was right behind me again!

And an easter egg to those who care to hear it: your clothes seem to give you power points, and by taking off all your clothes you will notice a difference in power.  Hope that helps!

As a fan of stealth games, this game has earned a spot on the list of favorites.  Top of the list?  Heavens, no!  Keep in mind, however, that this is a free game!  The controls are pretty tight and the guard AI is better than in most games, but you can tell the studio maybe could have ironed out some other issues a bit more. The button to get the elevator to work seemed a little off; I'm not sure if there is a sweet spot for it or what, I've played the game a few times now and sometimes it takes a few clicks to get the damn thing to take you up!  Speaking of elevators, the game sometimes has visual artifacts: I swear I could see an unused character just standing around behind the elevator.  Again, free game, a few bugs here and there are nothing compared to the great time you'll have.  The grappling hook feels right, and you can use it to get some pretty cool views when it comes to planning your paths.  Oh, speaking of planning: the Tiger is pretty damn smart.  Well done, Mr. Coder!  It seemed like everytime I thought I had shaken it off my tale it was right behind me again!

And an easter egg to those who care to hear it: your clothes seem to give you power points, and by taking off all your clothes you will notice a difference in power.  Hope that helps!

reviewText:
I've only given it a few runs, so I can't say the game always has the same problems, but I figure I should warn any prospective players about this one.

On the upside, the grappling hook. Seriously, this was one of the central focus points for the game, and it delivers. The tranq darts are useful, the vehicles mostly handle well, and the tiger... I shouldn't say too much about the tiger. But man. You will remember the tiger.

The downside? Let's see. Load times. First time out, they weren't that bad, but when I booted this up again to show some friends, it took five minutes to handle the initial load, and there were worse waits later for some of the effects. The elevator was a standout. One run, it goes the second I hit the button. Next time I played, I had time to make a sandwich before it even started to move. And the variable puzzles might add replay, but sometimes they were nearly impossible. The laser grid was tough but fair. The teleportation trick was innovative. But the extended tiger attack sequence pretty much sank the entire playthrough.

On top of that, the achievements might be bugged. I still haven't gotten several, despite earning them more than once.

Still, on the whole, this game was one of the best stealth action games I've ever played (up there with Dishonored, easily.)  Anyone interested in grappling hooks, tigers, or the enigmatic Dr. Langeskov should get it immediately.

reviewText:
Perhaps one of the most lackluster performances in years, dissapointed expectations feature in Dr. Langeskov, The Tiger, and The Terribly Cursed Emerald: A Whirlwind Heist, a 25-minute new play by William Pugh co-creator of the Stanley Parable. There is no doubt that audiences will regret their precious lost ticket money.

One mustn’t, of course, confuse quality with quantity. But putting this brief (but, to some, interminable) miniature into the vast space is that Steam is doing it no service at all. Value for money it ain’t. The Steam Theatre apparently could not afford decent stagehands and rumors circulate that a strike is imminent. Fortunately as the play costs no money, the would-be theatre-goer loses none (an important point).

The piece is divided into three disctinct but ultimately unrelated acts, beginning with what initially appears to be a museum, but turns out to be a large brick mansion with expansive grounds and many expensive art collections.  British comedian Simon Amstell voices the titular charactar on a crime spree of revenge to heist his family's heirloom emerald from the clutches of his nemesis the collector.  A live tiger features heavily in this scene which adds a sense of urgency to the act.  Storm effects and creative use of lighting bring a dramatic flair that the other two acts inexplicably lack.

The second act follows with a disjointed experimental music accompanied by randomly generated video output.  The set envelopes in flames fading to yet another rain shower. A heavy handed attempt at avant garde that fails to create the atmosphere disired and expected after the moody beginning.  Also the protagonist is notably lacking from this act. The attempted Victorian drama of the opening clashes with postmodernism tone of the second act resulting in a confusion that smacks of sophomority.

To top all of that off, the third act concludes with only Darkness.  Gone are the first and second acts' stunning if conflicting imagery replaced with nothing.  Nothing that is except unsettling screams and Tiger noises that leave the viewer most upset.  One wonders if any thought went into this act at all.

All in all, Dr. Langeskov, The Tiger, and The Terribly Cursed Emerald: A Whirlwind Heist brings disgrace upon the London Theatre.  It seems a most laughable attempt lacking in depth and thought.  Two thumbs down and my hat remains on.  When will an explanation of this inexcusable failure be forthcoming?

reviewText:
Dr. Langeskov, The Tiger, and The Terribly Cursed Emerald: A Whirlwind Heist is a free game from Crows Crows Crows.

You probably haven't heard of them.

Don't worry, a lot of people haven't. Perhaps if I told you that this game is created by one of The Stanley Parable's two creators, you would be interested. Ah, yes. The really great game that was the brain child of by Davey Wreden and William Pugh. It seems that the two creators had a bit of a falling out since they have now created their own separate studios and are working on separate, but similar projects. A shame, but I digress. William Pugh is the guy behind Dr. Langeskov, The Tiger, and The Terribly Cursed Emerald: A Whirlwind Heist and Crows Crows Crows.

Dr. Langeskov, The Tiger, and The Terribly Cursed Emerald: A Whirlwind Heist takes the same formula present The Stanley Parable and The Beginner's Guide. This is another walking simulator with a narrator telling you what to do. However, this game has a completely different tone than the one set in both of these games. While The Stanley Parable was about philosophy and choices, The Beginner's Guide was about something on a personal level. It differs from person to person and always leaves you feeling uncomfortable in your own skin. Dr. Langeskov, The Tiger, and The Terribly Cursed Emerald: A Whirlwind Heist is about unfortunate circumstances and comedy. There isn't much of an underlying message to the game and it feels a little bit disappointing considering William's previous track record. However, I can forgive this since the game is free and we had Justin Roiland, creator of Rick and Morty, and Simon Amstell, a British stand up comedian at the helm for the voices.

This game looks really great. It definitely has its own style to it and the colorful graphics support the comedic tone nicely. Unity was used really well for this game and seeing this style used for future releases by Crows Crows Crows is something I look forward to. While taking in the atmosphere, it's really easy to listen to Simon tell you what to do next to progress the same. A lot of people say he is like Stephen Merchant's role as Wheatley, but I feel it is more just tied to how both this game's narrator and Wheatley both fail at their own jobs and have British accents. If you're feeling adventurous and not quite ready to walk to the next room, then you will be hearing from Justin, as he is part of the additional voices. You will know Justin when you hear him.

As mentioned previously, this game is a walking simulator and has no gameplay. You press buttons and occasionally find little nit-nacks and unlock achivements. There is only one ending, so there isn't much incentive to play through this game multiple times. I cannot take a negative score to this, though, since this is a 15-30 minutes long game and having multiple endings would make this game as expansive as The Stanley Parable. Dr. Langeskov, The Tiger, and The Terribly Cursed Emerald: A Whirlwind Heist seems more like William's introduction back towards the Indie scene and as a way for him to bring attention to Crows Crows Crows.

Overall, I recommend this game to anyone who is a fan of The Stanley Parable and for anyone wondering if The Stanley Parable or The Beginner's Guide is worth buying. Since this game uses the same formula, I feel it is a good way for those on the fence have a better opportunity to make a decision. However, do not expect game play and do not expect multiple endings. Play it and enjoy it.

Hopefully, we see more out of Crows Crows Crows.

------------------------------------------------------------

As of December 30th, 2015, this game still does not allow you to unlock achivements. This seems to be a bug since other players were able to get them before.

What a clever game.

Pros:
* Good visuals.
* Great voiceacting.
* Characters feel real.
* Great humor.
* A lot of branching dialogue, dependant of what you do.
* It's FREE!!
* Only approx. 600MB.
* Similar to the Stanley Parable's Demo (It's a different game to the full game, play it, if you haven't).

Neutral:
* The whole game could be considered a twist.

Cons:
* No real choice.
* Game could've continued from the point it ended at and it would've been quite interesting without it feeling forced and too long. (Could've probably been twice as long)
* Weird design choices, that make no sense (like when you interact with something uninteractable, you just hear drumsticks).
* No real replay value.
* Some of the achievements STILL don't work for a lot of players.

reviewText:
For a free game, there's no reason not to try this, especially as lots of people seem to love it. I can't stand it though, I've played it once and tried it again a second time where I found something I missed the first time but that made it even worse. I do think that it suffers from a slight case of being overhyped, although I guess maybe I would say that as someone who disliked it.

I am fully prepared to admit that I may just be missing one key thing that would get me to understand why everyone else appears to love this game, that meta-narrative thing maybe, but I don't have it, and so that wasn't my experience. Also, it has no sound options in game, which is bloody stupid btw, so make sure you tweak the audio settings before you start.

I didn't find it particularly amusing, a few brief smiles and nothing else, the rest I hated. The story is meant to have some sort of meta-narrative to it, I think, but I don't particularly care for that and didn't really find that it came across well. Your interactions are clicking, crouching and zooming in slightly. Two of which I only found out about in my second playthrough but I can't see how they'd be useful anyway. Your choices when playing conist of a) doing what the designer wants, b) refusing for a bit and getting some dialogue and then doing what they wanted anyway. even though refusing is also something they wanted you to do, or c) refusing and doing nothing for the rest of your life until you die. If it's meant to be a commentary on how you can't account for everything the player can do then I wish I could see the point they're trying to make, but it really feels like they're just lampshading what you can't do, and I don't find that amusing, or that it furthers the genre in any way. There's various moments where the story questions why you didn't do what they want, while never giving you the option to do what they ask. Or if you can, I didn't find it.

The title is just obnoxious, it's like the kid in school who trys to be quirky to get attention and gets told to shut up and sit down all the time. I've taken to calling it Ocean's 11 Tiger.

I've not tried The Stanley Parable or similar so I can't comment on the similarity of the two.
